Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Evaluating the Geologic History and Impact of River Blockages Caused by Landslides in Taiwan
Award.AbstractNarration:
Taiwan commonly annually experiences significant natural disasters including typhoons and earthquakes that can trigger massive landslides. When landslides fall into rivers they form dams that block flow and lead to sediment deposition that gets preserved in the river valleys. These sediments can be measured and dated to gain an overall understanding of Taiwan?s tectonic and climatic history as they are both responsible for triggering landslides. Better understanding this behavior can assist in preparing for future events, including the geohazards brought forth from these dams that affect the safety of people who live in mountainous areas (such as the tragic 2009 Xiaolin Dam failure). This research will be conducted using high quality satellite imagery that is only available in Taiwan and other computerized data processing techniques as well as field studies. This project will be conducted at Academia Sinica?s Institute of Earth Sciences in Taipei, Taiwan under the mentorship of Dr. Yu-Chang Chan. This collaboration provides an opportunity to have access to unique data that will enable new understanding of landslide impacts in Taiwan and address their role in changing the physical landscape.

Taiwan is one of the most rapidly eroding and tectonically active regions in the world, allowing it to be the ultimate natural experiment for research in tectonic geomorphology (landscape evolution). Landslides are a widespread feature of erosion in Taiwan, with direct connection to tectonic and climatic processes. Dramatic landslide events associated with large earthquakes and typhoons, as well as the increase in sediment transport and deposition that result from them, highlight the role the landslides play in pacing and shaping landscape evolution in Taiwan. Few studies, however, have addressed the longer-term geomorphic record of past landslides events throughout the region on a national scale and few have specifically investigated the further-reaching roles that landslide dams have played. Landslide dams have been studied in mountainous regions around the world and have shown the long-term effects on river incision and landscape evolution. This project will document and study the diverse record of paleo-landslides dams in Taiwan attesting to their marks left in the landscape?s evolution, as well as controls on their spatial variation such as proximity to active faults, lithology, and historic typhoon density. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the Ministry of Science and Technology of Taiwan.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This study was the primary research component for my ongoing Masters in Geoscience that analyzes the geological processes that shape the northern region of the Hsuehshan and Central Mountain Ranges of Taiwan. Overall topographic evolution in Taiwan is hypothesized to be caused by tectonic and climate impacts which effect river channel geometry due to changes in sediment deposition and erosion. However, some surficial processes often occur to block the signatures of this control The focus of this EAPSI summer project investigated the origin and evolution of the landscape along a 20km stretch of the Upper Dajia River in the Heping area of Taiwan to gain an understanding of both these background controls and its inturruptions in viewing them.

Field studies and analysis of Digital Elevation Models (DEMs) that were only available through my host institution (Academia Sinica, Taipei, Taiwan) were used to explore landscape features and processes along the river valley including terraces (perched ancient river beds that are no longer active), landslides and current/former landslide river blockages, and river capture (when one watershed erodes drainage area away from another). These changes in river conditions lead to the development of the features observed in the study. Additionally, since these channels are highly sinuous (winding), the results are proposed to be a product of coupling between bank erosion and landslides, a process currently being further researched in tropical, tectonically-active mountain ranges like Taiwan. These features are important to understand because they are examples of processes that can complicate the "buisness as usual" conditions. By understanding these complications, we may be able to develop the know-how to see around them to get an un-obscured view of the background controls on the region. Findings from this project, such as the major river capture site between the heads of the Dajia and Lanyang Rivers, have lead to the early developments of a project that will investigate the hypothosized tectonic controls on this region with followup research soon to be performed.

Through this experience, my host, Dr. Yu-Chang Chan, was able to teach me more advanced skills in field work and utilizing DEMs that will be crucial in my future career in academia. In addition to performing my Master’s research, I was able to attend the 2015 FACET (Feedbacks and coupling Among Climate, Erosion and Tectonics during mountain building) Professional Meeting at National Taiwan University in Taipei (Taiwan) to network with other scientists and future colleagues from around that world collaborating with one another. This was a very important asset for my future career as I plan for my primary research goal will be centered on the earth surface processes in tectonically active regions, particularly Taiwan. Furthermore, current results of this project were able to be presented at the 2015 American Geophysical Union Fall Meeting in San Francisco, California.   Additionally this was a unique experience that allowed me to collaborate in a field where women are largely under-represeted.
